    align-items: center;
    justify-content: center;
    text-decoration: none;
    transition: filter 0.3s ease-in-out, box-shadow 0.3s ease-in-out;
  }
  a.button:hover, .button:hover {
    filter: brightness(95%);
  }
  chops-button, a.button, .button {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
    background: var(--chops-white);
    border-radius: 6px;
    --chops-button-padding: 0.25em 8px;
    margin: 0;
    margin-left: auto;
  }
  a.button, .button {
    padding: var(--chops-button-padding);
  }
  chops-button i.material-icons, a.button i.material-icons, .button i.material-icons {
    display: block;
    margin-right: 4px;
  }
  chops-button.emphasized, a.button.emphasized, .button.emphasized {
    background: var(--chops-primary-button-bg);
    color: var(--chops-primary-button-color);
    text-shadow: 1px 1px 3px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.25);
  }
  textarea, select, input {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
  }
  /* Note: decoupling heading levels from styles is useful for
  * accessibility because styles will not always line up with semantically
  * appropriate heading levels.
  */
  .medium-heading {
    font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
    font-weight: normal;
    line-height: 1;
    padding: 0.25em 0;
    color: var(--chops-link-color);
    margin: 0;
    margin-top: 0.25em;
    border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
  }
  .medium-heading chops-button {
    line-height: 1.6;
  }
  .input-grid {
    padding: 0.5em 0;
    display: grid;
    max-width: 100%;
    grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
    grid-template-columns: minmax(120px, max-content) 1fr;
    align-items: flex-start;
  }
  .input-grid label {
    font-weight: bold;
    text-align: right;
    word-wrap: break-word;
  }
  @media (max-width: 600px) {
    .input-grid label {
      margin-top: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      text-align: left;
    }
    .input-grid {
      grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      grid-template-columns: 100%;
    }
  }

        mr-app {
          display: block;
          padding-top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-top: -1px; /* Prevent a double border from showing up. */

          /* From shared-styles.js. */
          --mr-edit-field-padding: 0.125em 4px;
          --mr-edit-field-width: 90%;
          --mr-input-grid-gap: 6px;
          font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
          color: var(--chops-primary-font-color);
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
        }
        main {
          border-top: var(--chops-normal-border);
        }
        .snackbar-container {
          position: fixed;
          bottom: 1em;
          left: 1em;
          display: flex;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: flex-start;
          z-index: 1000;
        }
        /** Unfix <chops-snackbar> to allow stacking. */
        chops-snackbar {
          position: static;
          margin-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .project-alert {
          background: var(--chops-orange-50);
          color: var(--chops-field-error-color);
          display: block;
          font-weight: bold;
          text-align: center;
        }
      </style>


      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">

          <slot></slot>

    <mr-cue centered="" cueprefname="search_for_numbers" hidden=""></mr-cue>


          
      
        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }
        @media (max-width: 1126px) {
          .container-issue-content {
            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          }
          mr-issue-metadata {
            min-width: auto;
            max-width: auto;
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            min-height: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
          mr-issue-metadata, .issue-header-container {
            position: static;
          }
        }

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>

        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>

          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        Description #1 by nullf...@gmail.com (Aug 13, 2020)
      <option value="0" selected="">

      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>When a user is redirected to a URL using protocol scheme managed by another existing application("slack://" for instance) A message box appears prompting the user to approve or deny. <span class="line"><!---->When a user is redirected to a URL using protocol scheme managed by another existing application("slack://" for instance) A message box appears prompting the user to approve or deny. <!----></span><br>If there is no protocol handler for that scheme(say - Idonotexists://.. ) nothing will popup.<span class="line"><!---->If there is no protocol handler for that scheme(say - Idonotexists://.. ) nothing will popup.<!----></span><br>This distinction of existent and non-existent protocol handlers can be measured by monitoring the value of document.hasFocus()<span class="line"><!---->This distinction of existent and non-existent protocol handlers can be measured by monitoring the value of document.hasFocus()<!----></span><br><br>An attacker can use this in order to brute-force a predefined list of known protocol handlers and get an idea of what software is running on a targeted system.<span class="line"><!---->An attacker can use this in order to brute-force a predefined list of known protocol handlers and get an idea of what software is running on a targeted system.<!----></span><br><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 83.0.4103.116 stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 83.0.4103.116 stable<!----></span><br>Operating System: Windows 10<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Windows 10<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>In order to detect if a given handler exists on the victim, we take the following steps:<span class="line"><!---->In order to detect if a given handler exists on the victim, we take the following steps:<!----></span><br>First we dynamically generate a link that is made of the scheme we would like to detect like such -<span class="line"><!---->First we dynamically generate a link that is made of the scheme we would like to detect like such -<!----></span><br><br><a href="MyHandler://test" id="handler-link">link</a><span class="line"><!---->&lt;a href="MyHandler://test" id="handler-link"&gt;link&lt;/a&gt;<!----></span><br><br>Then we trigger the link and detect whether the document has focus:<span class="line"><!---->Then we trigger the link and detect whether the document has focus:<!----></span><br><br>document.getElementById('handler-link').click();<span class="line"><!---->document.getElementById('handler-link').click();<!----></span><br>handler_exists = !document.hasFocus();<span class="line"><!---->handler_exists = !document.hasFocus();<!----></span><br><br>Read the attached USAGE.txt file in order to get the PoC to work. it demonstrate how an attacker can brute force a list of URL handlers on a targeted machine.<span class="line"><!---->Read the attached USAGE.txt file in order to get the PoC to work. it demonstrate how an attacker can brute force a list of URL handlers on a targeted machine.<!----></span><br><br><br>Also attached is a word document explaining the vulnerability as well as its impact in more details.<span class="line"><!---->Also attached is a word document explaining the vulnerability as well as its impact in more details.<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes. If<b class="line"><!---->Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes. If<!----></b><br>this bug is included, how would you like to be credited?<b class="line"><!---->this bug is included, how would you like to be credited?<!----></b><br>Reporter credit: Rotem Kerner Twitter: @k1p0d<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Rotem Kerner Twitter: @k1p0d<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <strong><!---->Labels:</strong>
          
          Security_Severity-Low Security_Impact-Stable
          
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        Thanks for the report.<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the report.<!----></span><br><br>The report says: "Operating System: Windows 10"<span class="line"><!---->The report says: "Operating System: Windows 10"<!----></span><br>Can you please confirm that you were able to reproduce this on Windows?<span class="line"><!---->Can you please confirm that you were able to reproduce this on Windows?<!----></span><br><br>Also, if the worst that an attacker can do with this is to determine the list of installed software, it's probably not even a security bug but I'll mark it as Low out of an abundance of caution.<span class="line"><!---->Also, if the worst that an attacker can do with this is to determine the list of installed software, it's probably not even a security bug but I'll mark it as Low out of an abundance of caution.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        vakh@: I don't own this code and I'm not a Windows developer, sorry. Deciding what to do here should probably rest with the security enamel team.<span class="line"><!---->vakh@: I don't own this code and I'm not a Windows developer, sorry. Deciding what to do here should probably rest with the security enamel team.<!----></span><br><br>That said, I don't see how we would change this behavior even conceptually - it seems unavoidable that:<span class="line"><!---->That said, I don't see how we would change this behavior even conceptually - it seems unavoidable that:<!----></span><br><br>a) You can open a URL automatically from JS, even if it's an external scheme<span class="line"><!---->a) You can open a URL automatically from JS, even if it's an external scheme<!----></span><br>b) Opening an external scheme (which may open an entire new app) will take window focus away from chrome<span class="line"><!---->b) Opening an external scheme (which may open an entire new app) will take window focus away from chrome<!----></span><br>c) JS can detect that loss of window focus to tell whether an app was opened<span class="line"><!---->c) JS can detect that loss of window focus to tell whether an app was opened<!----></span><br><br>It's possible that "open external protocol handlers outside a small allow list" (mailto, etc) should be a permission the user needs to grant an origin? Right now, what happens is something like the attached dialog, which steals focus from the page if there's a valid handler but doesn't otherwise.<span class="line"><!---->It's possible that "open external protocol handlers outside a small allow list" (mailto, etc) should be a permission the user needs to grant an origin? Right now, what happens is something like the attached dialog, which steals focus from the page if there's a valid handler but doesn't otherwise.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Re #3, the dialog on the screenshot is, in a way, the permission prompt. I wonder if we should just pop open that dialog regardless of whether a protocol handler exists, and show some special text if it doesn't, so that focus is always taken.<span class="line"><!---->Re #3, the dialog on the screenshot is, in a way, the permission prompt. I wonder if we should just pop open that dialog regardless of whether a protocol handler exists, and show some special text if it doesn't, so that focus is always taken.<!----></span><br><br>I will let the security folks to determine the security classification of this, and in the meantime CC'ing privacy folks (sauski@) to see if they consider this a privacy issue.<span class="line"><!---->I will let the security folks to determine the security classification of this, and in the meantime CC'ing privacy folks (sauski@) to see if they consider this a privacy issue.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        From a privacy perspective, this at most seems like this just increases fingerprinting surface, but not even in a really usable way. If a protocol handler is installed, then a user will get a dialog prompt, and IIUC they will have to select yes/no for the focus check to be meaningful and allow the attack to continue to extract information. I can't imagine a website attempting to use this for cross site tracking, as this would risk prompting the user for protocols on every visit.<span class="line"><!---->From a privacy perspective, this at most seems like this just increases fingerprinting surface, but not even in a really usable way. If a protocol handler is installed, then a user will get a dialog prompt, and IIUC they will have to select yes/no for the focus check to be meaningful and allow the attack to continue to extract information. I can't imagine a website attempting to use this for cross site tracking, as this would risk prompting the user for protocols on every visit.<!----></span><br><br>CC'ing pauljensen@ from cross-site tracking prevention to weigh in on fingerprinting risk.<span class="line"><!---->CC'ing pauljensen@ from cross-site tracking prevention to weigh in on fingerprinting risk.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        >Just the prompt being shown steals focus already.<span class="line"><!---->&gt;Just the prompt being shown steals focus already.<!----></span><br><br>That gets them one handler though, right? I.e. they walk the list of handlers, when they hit one the user has a handler for, focus is lost. So they get the information that all the preceding handlers are not installed, and one single handler is installed. My understanding was that to continue to extract information, the user would have to reset the prompt so they could continue checking more handlers (otherwise there is already a prompt up and focus lost doesn't mean anything).<span class="line"><!---->That gets them one handler though, right? I.e. they walk the list of handlers, when they hit one the user has a handler for, focus is lost. So they get the information that all the preceding handlers are not installed, and one single handler is installed. My understanding was that to continue to extract information, the user would have to reset the prompt so they could continue checking more handlers (otherwise there is already a prompt up and focus lost doesn't mean anything).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        regarding what #14 says - <span class="line"><!---->regarding what #14 says - <!----></span><br>In the PoC i i came up with I was able to brute force a list of handlers and detect whether the handler exists or not. In case the Prompt was shown I redirect the user to a different domain(could be done with two different IPs though) which redirected once more to the initial page for the next protocol handler check.<span class="line"><!---->In the PoC i i came up with I was able to brute force a list of handlers and detect whether the handler exists or not.         I thought i'd add some words about the potential Impact of this vulnerability:<span class="line"><!---->I thought i'd add some words about the potential Impact of this vulnerability:<!----></span><br><br>Such information disclosure vulnerability could be exploited in several different ways.  Here are some examples:<span class="line"><!---->Such information disclosure vulnerability could be exploited in several different ways.  Here are some examples:<!----></span><br>* Identifying communication channels: By listing the handlers an attacker can get a hint to what platforms he may use for reaching the targeted user. For instance, detecting social applications such as slack, skype, whatsapp or telegram may be used for communicating with the target. <span class="line"><!---->* Identifying communication channels: By listing the handlers an attacker can get a hint to what platforms he may use for reaching the targeted user. For instance, detecting social applications such as slack, skype, whatsapp or telegram may be used for communicating with the target. <!----></span><br>* General reconnaissance: A wide range of applications nowadays uses custom URL handlers and can be detected using this vulnerability. Some examples: music players, IDE, office applications, crypto-mining, browsers, mail applications, antivirus, video conferencing, virtualizations, database clients, version control clients, chat clients, voice conference apps, shared storages<span class="line"><!---->* General reconnaissance: A wide range of applications nowadays uses custom URL handlers and can be detected using this vulnerability. Some examples: music players, IDE, office applications, crypto-mining, browsers, mail applications, antivirus, video conferencing, virtualizations, database clients, version control clients, chat clients, voice conference apps, shared storages<!----></span><br>* Pre-exploitation detection: Exploit kits may leverage this information in order to identify if a potentially vulnerable application is present without exposing the vulnerability itself. <span class="line"><!---->* Pre-exploitation detection: Exploit kits may leverage this information in order to identify if a potentially vulnerable application is present without exposing the vulnerability itself. <!----></span><br>* Detecting Security solutions: some security solutions whose presence can be exposed by leveraging the vulnerabilities because they have custom protocol handlers installed. Attackers may use this to further customize their attack to be able to circumvent any protection mechanism set by those security solutions.<span class="line"><!---->* Detecting Security solutions: some security solutions whose presence can be exposed by leveraging the vulnerabilities because they have custom protocol handlers installed. Attackers may use this to further customize their attack to be able to circumvent any protection mechanism set by those security solutions.<!----></span><br>* User Fingerprinting: reading what protocol handlers exist on a system may also be used in order to improve browser/user fingerprinting algorithms.<span class="line"><!---->* User Fingerprinting: reading what protocol handlers exist on a system may also be used in order to improve browser/user fingerprinting algorithms.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        RE <span class="line"><!---->RE <!----></span>pauljensen@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/pauljensen@chromium.org"><!---->pauljensen@chromium.org<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>#c12<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c12"><!---->#c12<!----></a>: FYI, this is related to, but not the same as the spec I think you're referring to that I reviewed [0], which involves letting PWAs register as protocol handlers -- native apps already can (and webpages already could too, but currently just for in-browser navigation), which makes the attack in this bug possible. <span class="line"><!---->: FYI, this is related to, but not the same as the spec I think you're referring to that I reviewed [0], which involves letting PWAs register as protocol handlers -- native apps already can (and webpages already could too, but currently just for in-browser navigation), which makes the attack in this bug possible. <!----></span><br><br>I agree with <span class="line"><!---->I agree with <!----></span>engedy@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/engedy@chromium.org"><!---->engedy@chromium.org<!----></a>'s assessment in <span class="line"><!---->'s assessment in <!----></span>#c9<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c9"><!---->#c9<!----></a>; if we always put up a dialog regardless of whether a suitable application is installed or not, scripts wouldn't be able to use this method to determine the set of installed protocol-handling applications. I think the UX might even be a bit nicer, since the user can realize why a protocol link isn't opening. <span class="line"><!---->; if we always put up a dialog regardless of whether a suitable application is installed or not, scripts wouldn't be able to use this method to determine the set of installed protocol-handling applications. I think the UX might even be a bit nicer, since the user can realize why a protocol link isn't opening. <!----></span><br><br>I also agree that this a fingerprinting concern, as the exact set of installed apps that handle protocol URLs is likely to be unique per-user, and the domain redirection trick allows (somewhat awkwardly, given that it's user-visible) sites to query multiple protocol URLs quickly, increasing the amount of learned entropy. This information can be accumulated into a first-party cookie or other first-party storage on the first domain, so no link decoration between the 2 domains or third-party cookies are required.<span class="line"><!---->I also agree that this a fingerprinting concern, as the exact set of installed apps that handle protocol URLs is likely to be unique per-user, and the domain redirection trick allows (somewhat awkwardly, given that it's user-visible) sites to query multiple protocol URLs quickly, increasing the amount of learned entropy. This information can be accumulated into a first-party cookie or other first-party storage on the first domain, so no link decoration between the 2 domains or third-party cookies are required.<!----></span><br><br>One complication is that I suspect the current behavior helps enable things like deferred deep linking [1] on mobile platforms. Web sites first attempt to load the app, and if that fails, redirect to that app's store listing [2]. I think we wouldn't break this, but we'd possibly add another dialog in the flow. It would definitely be good for the security enamel team and folks with more experience in this area to weigh in. <span class="line"><!---->One complication is that I suspect the current behavior helps enable things like deferred deep linking [1] on mobile platforms. Web sites first attempt to load the app, and if that fails, redirect to that app's store listing [2]. I think we wouldn't break this, but we'd possibly add another dialog in the flow. It would definitely be good for the security enamel team and folks with more experience in this area to weigh in. <!----></span><br><br>cthomp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/cthomp@chromium.org"><!---->cthomp@chromium.org<!----></a> -- can you comment for the enamel team on this UX change?<span class="line"><!----> -- can you comment for the enamel team on this UX change?<!----></span><br><br>On Linux and Chrome OS, it appears a dialog does always appear currently -- I can confirm that on Windows and Android that no dialog is displayed if there is no handler installed. I didn't test on Mac, iOS, or other platforms. It'd also be interesting to see how Safari on iOS behaves, and what UX change is possible given iOS limitations. <span class="line"><!---->On Linux and Chrome OS, it appears a dialog does always appear currently -- I can confirm that on Windows and Android that no dialog is displayed if there is no handler installed. I didn't test on Mac, iOS, or other platforms. It'd also be interesting to see how Safari on iOS behaves, and what UX change is possible given iOS limitations. <!----></span><br><br>[0] <span class="line"><!---->[0] <!----></span>https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/forum/#!msg/blink-dev/2Sv3fCWEi_Q/yrSoJP8mAAAJ<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/forum/#!msg/blink-dev/2Sv3fCWEi_Q/yrSoJP8mAAAJ"><!---->https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/forum/#!msg/blink-dev/2Sv3fCWEi_Q/yrSoJP8mAAAJ<!----></a><br><br>[1] <span class="line"><!---->[1] <!----></span>https://www.appsflyer.com/resources/everything-marketer-needs-to-know-deep-linking/deferred-deep-linking/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.appsflyer.com/resources/everything-marketer-needs-to-know-deep-linking/deferred-deep-linking/"><!---->https://www.appsflyer.com/resources/everything-marketer-needs-to-know-deep-linking/deferred-deep-linking/<!----></a><br><br>[2] <span class="line"><!---->[2] <!----></span>https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13044805/how-to-check-if-an-app-is-installed-from-a-web-page-on-an-iphone<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13044805/how-to-check-if-an-app-is-installed-from-a-web-page-on-an-iphone"><!---->https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13044805/how-to-check-if-an-app-is-installed-from-a-web-page-on-an-iphone<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        by

          Cc:<strong><!---->Cc:</strong>
          
          est...@chromium.org
          
          <br>
        
        
      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Cc:</strong>
          
          est...@chromium.org
          
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        +estark@ who has been involved in other efforts around the protocol handler dialog.<span class="line"><!---->+estark@ who has been involved in other efforts around the protocol handler dialog.<!----></span><br><br>I don't think there would be any *security UX* concerns with opening the dialog even if there doesn't exist a registered protocol handler for it, although we would need to come up with the strings to use in that case so that it doesn't feel weird/broken. Some (very rough) brainstorming:<span class="line"><!---->I don't think there would be any *security UX* concerns with opening the dialog even if there doesn't exist a registered protocol handler for it, although we would need to come up with the strings to use in that case so that it doesn't feel weird/broken. Some (very rough) brainstorming:<!----></span><br><br>Title: "Cannot handle"<span class="line"><!---->Title: "Cannot handle"<!----></span><br>Text: "<origin> wants to open an application to handle <protocol>, but none exists."<span class="line"><!---->Text: "&lt;origin&gt; wants to open an application to handle &lt;protocol&gt;, but none exists."<!----></span><br><br>The downside of this is that there is no action we can present to the user in this case, so I think this would always feel a bit broken/wrong (and why we haven't shown the dialog in these cases before), which feels a little insurmountable to me.<span class="line"><!---->The downside of this is that there is no action we can present to the user in this case, so I think this would always feel a bit broken/wrong (and why we haven't shown the dialog in these cases before), which feels a little insurmountable to me.<!----></span><br><br>Also, if we make it always pop up, should we make sure this dialog can be stopped by the user if the site is spamming it, like we do for e.g. alerts?<span class="line"><!---->Also, if we make it always pop up, should we make sure this dialog can be stopped by the user if the site is spamming it, like we do for e.g. alerts?<!----></span><br><br>As this is still primarily a fingerprinting vector, I think this is less a security bug and more a privacy bug, but I do think it should be addressed. See <span class="line"><!---->As this is still primarily a fingerprinting vector, I think this is less a security bug and more a privacy bug, but I do think it should be addressed. See <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#What-is-Chrome_s-threat-model-for-fingerprinting<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#What-is-Chrome_s-threat-model-for-fingerprinting"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#What-is-Chrome_s-threat-model-for-fingerprinting<!----></a> for our reasoning about how we (Chrome Security) think about the threat model for fingerprinting.<span class="line"><!----> for our reasoning about how we (Chrome Security) think about the threat model for fingerprinting.<!----></span><br><br>Ideally, trying to open a protocol handler (or querying whether one is installed) would cost some amount of "privacy budget", since it is an active fingerprinting surface. So maybe this would be a temporary fix until we have our broader anti-fingerprinting work in place.<span class="line"><!---->Ideally, trying to open a protocol handler (or querying whether one is installed) would cost some amount of "privacy budget", since it is an active fingerprinting surface. So maybe this would be a temporary fix until we have our broader anti-fingerprinting work in place.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

If this is correct, I'm significantly less worried about this vulnerability as compared to fingerprinting mechanisms that don't have user-discernable UI.  Would still be nice to fix this one of course.<span class="line"><!---->Can you help me better understand this proposed vulnerability:  To calculate a fingerprint the site would need to surface several dialogs to the user, correct?         >> To calculate a fingerprint the site would need to surface several dialogs to the user, correct?  If this is correct, I'm significantly less worried about this vulnerability as compared to fingerprinting mechanisms that don't have user-discernable UI. <span class="line"><!---->&gt;&gt; To calculate a fingerprint the site would need to surface several dialogs to the user, correct?  If this is correct, I'm significantly less worried about this vulnerability as compared to fingerprinting mechanisms that don't have user-discernable UI. <!----></span><br><br>This is correct. Although the drawback of this attack is that it is not a silent one. It still worth considering that the use of it may go reach beyond the scope of fingerprinting. Here are the other issues I've identified -<span class="line"><!---->This is correct. Although the drawback of this attack is that it is not a silent one. It still worth considering that the use of it may go reach beyond the scope of fingerprinting. Here are the other issues I've identified -<!----></span><br>* General reconnaissance: A wide range of applications nowadays uses custom URL handlers and can be detected using this vulnerability. Some examples: music players, IDE, office applications, crypto-mining, browsers, mail applications, antivirus, video conferencing, virtualizations, database clients, version control clients, chat clients, voice conference apps, shared storages<span class="line"><!---->* General reconnaissance: A wide range of applications nowadays uses custom URL handlers and can be detected using this vulnerability. Some examples: music players, IDE, office applications, crypto-mining, browsers, mail applications, antivirus, video conferencing, virtualizations, database clients, version control clients, chat clients, voice conference apps, shared storages<!----></span><br>* Pre-exploitation detection: Exploit kits may leverage this information in order to identify if a potentially vulnerable application is present without exposing the vulnerability itself. <span class="line"><!---->* Pre-exploitation detection: Exploit kits may leverage this information in order to identify if a potentially vulnerable application is present without exposing the vulnerability itself. <!----></span><br>* Detecting Security solutions: some security solutions whose presence can be exposed by leveraging the vulnerabilities because they have custom protocol handlers installed. Attackers may use this to further customize their attack to be able to circumvent any protection mechanism set by those security solutions.<span class="line"><!---->* Detecting Security solutions: some security solutions whose presence can be exposed by leveraging the vulnerabilities because they have custom protocol handlers installed. Attackers may use this to further customize their attack to be able to circumvent any protection mechanism set by those security solutions.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

           issue<h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          
            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

        mr-issue-page {

          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);

          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

      
      
        
          <slot></slot>
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      <dialog class="dialog" role="dialog">
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>

        Description #1 by nullf...@gmail.com (Aug 13, 2020)
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by nullf...@gmail.com (Aug 13, 2020)
      </option>
    
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by nullf...@gmail.com (Aug 13, 2020)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by nullf...@gmail.com (Aug 13, 2020)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>When a user is redirected to a URL using protocol scheme managed by another existing application("slack://" for instance) A message box appears prompting the user to approve or deny. <span class="line"><!---->When a user is redirected to a URL using protocol scheme managed by another existing application("slack://" for instance) A message box appears prompting the user to approve or deny. <!----></span><br>If there is no protocol handler for that scheme(say - Idonotexists://.. ) nothing will popup.<span class="line"><!---->If there is no protocol handler for that scheme(say - Idonotexists://.. ) nothing will popup.<!----></span><br>This distinction of existent and non-existent protocol handlers can be measured by monitoring the value of document.hasFocus()<span class="line"><!---->This distinction of existent and non-existent protocol handlers can be measured by monitoring the value of document.hasFocus()<!----></span><br><br>An attacker can use this in order to brute-force a predefined list of known protocol handlers and get an idea of what software is running on a targeted system.<span class="line"><!---->An attacker can use this in order to brute-force a predefined list of known protocol handlers and get an idea of what software is running on a targeted system.<!----></span><br><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 83.0.4103.116 stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 83.0.4103.116 stable<!----></span><br>Operating System: Windows 10<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Windows 10<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>In order to detect if a given handler exists on the victim, we take the following steps:<span class="line"><!---->In order to detect if a given handler exists on the victim, we take the following steps:<!----></span><br>First we dynamically generate a link that is made of the scheme we would like to detect like such -<span class="line"><!---->First we dynamically generate a link that is made of the scheme we would like to detect like such -<!----></span><br><br><a href="MyHandler://test" id="handler-link">link</a><span class="line"><!---->&lt;a href="MyHandler://test" id="handler-link"&gt;link&lt;/a&gt;<!----></span><br><br>Then we trigger the link and detect whether the document has focus:<span class="line"><!---->Then we trigger the link and detect whether the document has focus:<!----></span><br><br>document.getElementById('handler-link').click();<span class="line"><!---->document.getElementById('handler-link').click();<!----></span><br>handler_exists = !document.hasFocus();<span class="line"><!---->handler_exists = !document.hasFocus();<!----></span><br><br>Read the attached USAGE.txt file in order to get the PoC to work. it demonstrate how an attacker can brute force a list of URL handlers on a targeted machine.<span class="line"><!---->Read the attached USAGE.txt file in order to get the PoC to work. it demonstrate how an attacker can brute force a list of URL handlers on a targeted machine.<!----></span><br><br><br>Also attached is a word document explaining the vulnerability as well as its impact in more details.<span class="line"><!---->Also attached is a word document explaining the vulnerability as well as its impact in more details.<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes. If<b class="line"><!---->Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes. If<!----></b><br>this bug is included, how would you like to be credited?<b class="line"><!---->this bug is included, how would you like to be credited?<!----></b><br>Reporter credit: Rotem Kerner Twitter: @k1p0d<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Rotem Kerner Twitter: @k1p0d<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        vakh@: I don't own this code and I'm not a Windows developer, sorry. Deciding what to do here should probably rest with the security enamel team.<span class="line"><!---->vakh@: I don't own this code and I'm not a Windows developer, sorry. Deciding what to do here should probably rest with the security enamel team.<!----></span><br><br>That said, I don't see how we would change this behavior even conceptually - it seems unavoidable that:<span class="line"><!---->That said, I don't see how we would change this behavior even conceptually - it seems unavoidable that:<!----></span><br><br>a) You can open a URL automatically from JS, even if it's an external scheme<span class="line"><!---->a) You can open a URL automatically from JS, even if it's an external scheme<!----></span><br>b) Opening an external scheme (which may open an entire new app) will take window focus away from chrome<span class="line"><!---->b) Opening an external scheme (which may open an entire new app) will take window focus away from chrome<!----></span><br>c) JS can detect that loss of window focus to tell whether an app was opened<span class="line"><!---->c) JS can detect that loss of window focus to tell whether an app was opened<!----></span><br><br>It's possible that "open external protocol handlers outside a small allow list" (mailto, etc) should be a permission the user needs to grant an origin? Right now, what happens is something like the attached dialog, which steals focus from the page if there's a valid handler but doesn't otherwise.<span class="line"><!---->It's possible that "open external protocol handlers outside a small allow list" (mailto, etc) should be a permission the user needs to grant an origin? Right now, what happens is something like the attached dialog, which steals focus from the page if there's a valid handler but doesn't otherwise.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Re #3, the dialog on the screenshot is, in a way, the permission prompt. I wonder if we should just pop open that dialog regardless of whether a protocol handler exists, and show some special text if it doesn't, so that focus is always taken.<span class="line"><!---->Re #3, the dialog on the screenshot is, in a way, the permission prompt. I wonder if we should just pop open that dialog regardless of whether a protocol handler exists, and show some special text if it doesn't, so that focus is always taken.<!----></span><br><br>I will let the security folks to determine the security classification of this, and in the meantime CC'ing privacy folks (sauski@) to see if they consider this a privacy issue.<span class="line"><!---->I will let the security folks to determine the security classification of this, and in the meantime CC'ing privacy folks (sauski@) to see if they consider this a privacy issue.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1115943#c11">Comment 11<!----></a>

          
        by

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1115943#c11">Comment 11<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Sep 1, 2020, 10:55 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        From a privacy perspective, this at most seems like this just increases fingerprinting surface, but not even in a really usable way. If a protocol handler is installed, then a user will get a dialog prompt, and IIUC they will have to select yes/no for the focus check to be meaningful and allow the attack to continue to extract information. I can't imagine a website attempting to use this for cross site tracking, as this would risk prompting the user for protocols on every visit.<span class="line"><!---->From a privacy perspective, this at most seems like this just increases fingerprinting surface, but not even in a really usable way. If a protocol handler is installed, then a user will get a dialog prompt, and IIUC they will have to select yes/no for the focus check to be meaningful and allow the attack to continue to extract information. I can't imagine a website attempting to use this for cross site tracking, as this would risk prompting the user for protocols on every visit.<!----></span><br><br>CC'ing pauljensen@ from cross-site tracking prevention to weigh in on fingerprinting risk.<span class="line"><!---->CC'ing pauljensen@ from cross-site tracking prevention to weigh in on fingerprinting risk.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        >Just the prompt being shown steals focus already.<span class="line"><!---->&gt;Just the prompt being shown steals focus already.<!----></span><br><br>That gets them one handler though, right? I.e. they walk the list of handlers, when they hit one the user has a handler for, focus is lost. So they get the information that all the preceding handlers are not installed, and one single handler is installed. My understanding was that to continue to extract information, the user would have to reset the prompt so they could continue checking more handlers (otherwise there is already a prompt up and focus lost doesn't mean anything).<span class="line"><!---->That gets them one handler though, right? I.e. they walk the list of handlers, when they hit one the user has a handler for, focus is lost. So they get the information that all the preceding handlers are not installed, and one single handler is installed. My understanding was that to continue to extract information, the user would have to reset the prompt so they could continue checking more handlers (otherwise there is already a prompt up and focus lost doesn't mean anything).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        regarding what #14 says - <span class="line"><!---->regarding what #14 says - <!----></span><br>In the PoC i i came up with I was able to brute force a list of handlers and detect whether the handler exists or not. In case the Prompt was shown I redirect the user to a different domain(could be done with two different IPs though) which redirected once more to the initial page for the next protocol handler check.<span class="line"><!---->In the PoC i i came up with I was able to brute force a list of handlers and detect whether the handler exists or not. In case the Prompt was shown I redirect the user to a different domain(could be done with two different IPs though) which redirected once more to the initial page for the next protocol handler check.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        I thought i'd add some words about the potential Impact of this vulnerability:<span class="line"><!---->I thought i'd add some words about the potential Impact of this vulnerability:<!----></span><br><br>Such information disclosure vulnerability could be exploited in several different ways.  Here are some examples:<span class="line"><!---->Such information disclosure vulnerability could be exploited in several different ways.  Here are some examples:<!----></span><br>* Identifying communication channels: By listing the handlers an attacker can get a hint to what platforms he may use for reaching the targeted user. For instance, detecting social applications such as slack, skype, whatsapp or telegram may be used for communicating with the target. <span class="line"><!---->* Identifying communication channels: By listing the handlers an attacker can get a hint to what platforms he may use for reaching the targeted user. For instance, detecting social applications such as slack, skype, whatsapp or telegram may be used for communicating with the target. <!----></span><br>* General reconnaissance: A wide range of applications nowadays uses custom URL handlers and can be detected using this vulnerability. Some examples: music players, IDE, office applications, crypto-mining, browsers, mail applications, antivirus, video conferencing, virtualizations, database clients, version control clients, chat clients, voice conference apps, shared storages<span class="line"><!---->* General reconnaissance: A wide range of applications nowadays uses custom URL handlers and can be detected using this vulnerability. Some examples: music players, IDE, office applications, crypto-mining, browsers, mail applications, antivirus, video conferencing, virtualizations, database clients, version control clients, chat clients, voice conference apps, shared storages<!----></span><br>* Pre-exploitation detection: Exploit kits may leverage this information in order to identify if a potentially vulnerable application is present without exposing the vulnerability itself. <span class="line"><!---->* Pre-exploitation detection: Exploit kits may leverage this information in order to identify if a potentially vulnerable application is present without exposing the vulnerability itself. <!----></span><br>* Detecting Security solutions: some security solutions whose presence can be exposed by leveraging the vulnerabilities because they have custom protocol handlers installed. Attackers may use this to further customize their attack to be able to circumvent any protection mechanism set by those security solutions.<span class="line"><!---->* Detecting Security solutions: some security solutions whose presence can be exposed by leveraging the vulnerabilities because they have custom protocol handlers installed. Attackers may use this to further customize their attack to be able to circumvent any protection mechanism set by those security solutions.<!----></span><br>* User Fingerprinting: reading what protocol handlers exist on a system may also be used in order to improve browser/user fingerprinting algorithms.<span class="line"><!---->* User Fingerprinting: reading what protocol handlers exist on a system may also be used in order to improve browser/user fingerprinting algorithms.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        RE <span class="line"><!---->RE <!----></span>pauljensen@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/pauljensen@chromium.org"><!---->pauljensen@chromium.org<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>#c12<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c12"><!---->#c12<!----></a>: FYI, this is related to, but not the same as the spec I think you're referring to that I reviewed [0], which involves letting PWAs register as protocol handlers -- native apps already can (and webpages already could too, but currently just for in-browser navigation), which makes the attack in this bug possible. <span class="line"><!---->: FYI, this is related to, but not the same as the spec I think you're referring to that I reviewed [0], which involves letting PWAs register as protocol handlers -- native apps already can (and webpages already could too, but currently just for in-browser navigation), which makes the attack in this bug possible. <!----></span><br><br>I agree with <span class="line"><!---->I agree with <!----></span>engedy@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/engedy@chromium.org"><!---->engedy@chromium.org<!----></a>'s assessment in <span class="line"><!---->'s assessment in <!----></span>#c9<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c9"><!---->#c9<!----></a>; if we always put up a dialog regardless of whether a suitable application is installed or not, scripts wouldn't be able to use this method to determine the set of installed protocol-handling applications. I think the UX might even be a bit nicer, since the user can realize why a protocol link isn't opening. <span class="line"><!---->; if we always put up a dialog regardless of whether a suitable application is installed or not, scripts wouldn't be able to use this method to determine the set of installed protocol-handling applications. I think the UX might even be a bit nicer, since the user can realize why a protocol link isn't opening. <!----></span><br><br>I also agree that this a fingerprinting concern, as the exact set of installed apps that handle protocol URLs is likely to be unique per-user, and the domain redirection trick allows (somewhat awkwardly, given that it's user-visible) sites to query multiple protocol URLs quickly, increasing the amount of learned entropy. This information can be accumulated into a first-party cookie or other first-party storage on the first domain, so no link decoration between the 2 domains or third-party cookies are required.<span class="line"><!---->I also agree that this a fingerprinting concern, as the exact set of installed apps that handle protocol URLs is likely to be unique per-user, and the domain redirection trick allows (somewhat awkwardly, given that it's user-visible) sites to query multiple protocol URLs quickly, increasing the amount of learned entropy. This information can be accumulated into a first-party cookie or other first-party storage on the first domain, so no link decoration between the 2 domains or third-party cookies are required.<!----></span><br><br>One complication is that I suspect the current behavior helps enable things like deferred deep linking [1] on mobile platforms. Web sites first attempt to load the app, and if that fails, redirect to that app's store listing [2]. I think we wouldn't break this, but we'd possibly add another dialog in the flow. It would definitely be good for the security enamel team and folks with more experience in this area to weigh in. <span class="line"><!---->One complication is that I suspect the current behavior helps enable things like deferred deep linking [1] on mobile platforms. Web sites first attempt to load the app, and if that fails, redirect to that app's store listing [2]. I think we wouldn't break this, but we'd possibly add another dialog in the flow. It would definitely be good for the security enamel team and folks with more experience in this area to weigh in. <!----></span><br><br>cthomp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/cthomp@chromium.org"><!---->cthomp@chromium.org<!----></a> -- can you comment for the enamel team on this UX change?<span class="line"><!----> -- can you comment for the enamel team on this UX change?<!----></span><br><br>On Linux and Chrome OS, it appears a dialog does always appear currently -- I can confirm that on Windows and Android that no dialog is displayed if there is no handler installed. I didn't test on Mac, iOS, or other platforms. It'd also be interesting to see how Safari on iOS behaves, and what UX change is possible given iOS limitations. <span class="line"><!---->On Linux and Chrome OS, it appears a dialog does always appear currently -- I can confirm that on Windows and Android that no dialog is displayed if there is no handler installed. I didn't test on Mac, iOS, or other platforms. It'd also be interesting to see how Safari on iOS behaves, and what UX change is possible given iOS limitations. <!----></span><br><br>[0] <span class="line"><!---->[0] <!----></span>https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/forum/#!msg/blink-dev/2Sv3fCWEi_Q/yrSoJP8mAAAJ<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/forum/#!msg/blink-dev/2Sv3fCWEi_Q/yrSoJP8mAAAJ"><!---->https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/forum/#!msg/blink-dev/2Sv3fCWEi_Q/yrSoJP8mAAAJ<!----></a><br><br>[1] <span class="line"><!---->[1] <!----></span>https://www.appsflyer.com/resources/everything-marketer-needs-to-know-deep-linking/deferred-deep-linking/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.appsflyer.com/resources/everything-marketer-needs-to-know-deep-linking/deferred-deep-linking/"><!---->https://www.appsflyer.com/resources/everything-marketer-needs-to-know-deep-linking/deferred-deep-linking/<!----></a><br><br>[2] <span class="line"><!---->[2] <!----></span>https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13044805/how-to-check-if-an-app-is-installed-from-a-web-page-on-an-iphone<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13044805/how-to-check-if-an-app-is-installed-from-a-web-page-on-an-iphone"><!---->https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13044805/how-to-check-if-an-app-is-installed-from-a-web-page-on-an-iphone<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        +estark@ who has been involved in other efforts around the protocol handler dialog.<span class="line"><!---->+estark@ who has been involved in other efforts around the protocol handler dialog.<!----></span><br><br>I don't think there would be any *security UX* concerns with opening the dialog even if there doesn't exist a registered protocol handler for it, although we would need to come up with the strings to use in that case so that it doesn't feel weird/broken. Some (very rough) brainstorming:<span class="line"><!---->I don't think there would be any *security UX* concerns with opening the dialog even if there doesn't exist a registered protocol handler for it, although we would need to come up with the strings to use in that case so that it doesn't feel weird/broken. Some (very rough) brainstorming:<!----></span><br><br>Title: "Cannot handle"<span class="line"><!---->Title: "Cannot handle"<!----></span><br>Text: "<origin> wants to open an application to handle <protocol>, but none exists."<span class="line"><!---->Text: "&lt;origin&gt; wants to open an application to handle &lt;protocol&gt;, but none exists."<!----></span><br><br>The downside of this is that there is no action we can present to the user in this case, so I think this would always feel a bit broken/wrong (and why we haven't shown the dialog in these cases before), which feels a little insurmountable to me.<span class="line"><!---->The downside of this is that there is no action we can present to the user in this case, so I think this would always feel a bit broken/wrong (and why we haven't shown the dialog in these cases before), which feels a little insurmountable to me.<!----></span><br><br>Also, if we make it always pop up, should we make sure this dialog can be stopped by the user if the site is spamming it, like we do for e.g. alerts?<span class="line"><!---->Also, if we make it always pop up, should we make sure this dialog can be stopped by the user if the site is spamming it, like we do for e.g. alerts?<!----></span><br><br>As this is still primarily a fingerprinting vector, I think this is less a security bug and more a privacy bug, but I do think it should be addressed. See <span class="line"><!---->As this is still primarily a fingerprinting vector, I think this is less a security bug and more a privacy bug, but I do think it should be addressed. See <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#What-is-Chrome_s-threat-model-for-fingerprinting<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#What-is-Chrome_s-threat-model-for-fingerprinting"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#What-is-Chrome_s-threat-model-for-fingerprinting<!----></a> for our reasoning about how we (Chrome Security) think about the threat model for fingerprinting.<span class="line"><!----> for our reasoning about how we (Chrome Security) think about the threat model for fingerprinting.<!----></span><br><br>Ideally, trying to open a protocol handler (or querying whether one is installed) would cost some amount of "privacy budget", since it is an active fingerprinting surface. So maybe this would be a temporary fix until we have our broader anti-fingerprinting work in place.<span class="line"><!---->Ideally, trying to open a protocol handler (or querying whether one is installed) would cost some amount of "privacy budget", since it is an active fingerprinting surface. So maybe this would be a temporary fix until we have our broader anti-fingerprinting work in place.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I'm not sure a CVE makes sense for fingerprinting while Chrome supports third party cookies.<span class="line"><!---->I'm not sure a CVE makes sense for fingerprinting while Chrome supports third party cookies.<!----></span><br><br>Can you help me better understand this proposed vulnerability:  To calculate a fingerprint the site would need to surface several dialogs to the user, correct?  If this is correct, I'm significantly less worried about this vulnerability as compared to fingerprinting mechanisms that don't have user-discernable UI.  Would still be nice to fix this one of course.<span class="line"><!---->Can you help me better understand this proposed vulnerability:  To calculate a fingerprint the site would need to surface several dialogs to the user, correct?         >> To calculate a fingerprint the site would need to surface several dialogs to the user, correct?  If this is correct, I'm significantly less worried about this vulnerability as compared to fingerprinting mechanisms that don't have user-discernable UI. <span class="line"><!---->&gt;&gt; To calculate a fingerprint the site would need to surface several dialogs to the user, correct?  If this is correct, I'm significantly less worried about this vulnerability as compared to fingerprinting mechanisms that don't have user-discernable UI. <!----></span><br><br>This is correct. Although the drawback of this attack is that it is not a silent one. It still worth considering that the use of it may go reach beyond the scope of fingerprinting. Here are the other issues I've identified -<span class="line"><!---->This is correct. Although the drawback of this attack is that it is not a silent one. It still worth considering that the use of it may go reach beyond the scope of fingerprinting. Here are the other issues I've identified -<!----></span><br>* General reconnaissance: A wide range of applications nowadays uses custom URL handlers and can be detected using this vulnerability. Some examples: music players, IDE, office applications, crypto-mining, browsers, mail applications, antivirus, video conferencing, virtualizations, database clients, version control clients, chat clients, voice conference apps, shared storages<span class="line"><!---->* General reconnaissance: A wide range of applications nowadays uses custom URL handlers and can be detected using this vulnerability. Some examples: music players, IDE, office applications, crypto-mining, browsers, mail applications, antivirus, video conferencing, virtualizations, database clients, version control clients, chat clients, voice conference apps, shared storages<!----></span><br>* Pre-exploitation detection: Exploit kits may leverage this information in order to identify if a potentially vulnerable application is present without exposing the vulnerability itself. <span class="line"><!---->* Pre-exploitation detection: Exploit kits may leverage this information in order to identify if a potentially vulnerable application is present without exposing the vulnerability itself. <!----></span><br>* Detecting Security solutions: some security solutions whose presence can be exposed by leveraging the vulnerabilities because they have custom protocol handlers installed. Attackers may use this to further customize their attack to be able to circumvent any protection mechanism set by those security solutions.<span class="line"><!---->* Detecting Security solutions: some security solutions whose presence can be exposed by leveraging the vulnerabilities because they have custom protocol handlers installed. Attackers may use this to further customize their attack to be able to circumvent any protection mechanism set by those security solutions.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
